review.title: Measuring Player's Behaviour Change over Time in Public Goods Game
review.abstract: An important issue in public goods game is whether player's behaviour changes over time, and if so, how significant it is. In this game players can be classified into different groups according to the level of their participation in the public good. This problem can be considered as a concept drift problem by asking the amount of change that happens to the clusters of players over a sequence of game rounds. In this study we present a method for measuring changes in clusters with the same items over discrete time points using external clustering validation indices and area under the curve. External clustering indices were originally used to measure the difference between suggested clusters in terms of clustering algorithms and ground truth labels for items provided by experts. Instead of different cluster label comparison, we use these indices to compare between clusters of any two consecutive time points or between the first time point and the remaining time points to measure the difference between clusters through time points. In theory, any external clustering indices can be used to measure changes for any traditional (non-temporal) clustering algorithm, due to the fact that any time point alone is not carrying any temporal information. For the public goods game, our results indicate that the players are changing over time but the change is smooth and relatively constant between any two time points.

sections.heading: II. BACKGROUND AND RELATED WORK
sections.text: This paper uses data from the public goods game as a case study and several data mining principles such as external cluster validity, sub-curve area and data analysis methods to detect cluster changes in data flows. These topics will be reviewed in the next sections and present the relationship between the subject and our study.IEEE 637 | P a g eSAI Intelligent Systems Conference 2016 September 20-22, 2016 | London, UK

sections.heading: B. External Cluster Validity
sections.text: The main task of this approach is to determine a statistical measure of similarity or dissimilarity between the obtained clusters and labels. Each element of this matrix contains a number of agreed instances between any two clusters of the externally provided and produced clusters. As introduced by Meil [19], this index calculates mutual information and entropy between previously provided and produced clusters based on contingency table V I (C, T) = 2H (T, C) − H (C), where C is produced clusters and T.

sections.heading: III. METHODOLOGY
sections.text: In order to measure changes in the behavior of items or deviations from their original status, there should be at least one measurement value for the same attributes considered at different times. Data should be divided into multiple segments based on the number of consecutive measurements of the items, so that each data segment contains a single value of these measurements at any given time. Items at each point of time should be clustered using the same cluster algorithm and identical parameters (such as the number of clusters). After clustering, each item will be a member of a single cluster at any given time. For consistent times, items may belong to the same clusters or they may drift from one cluster to another. The first is the quantification of deviations (change in labeling) between any two points of time by using external cluster validity. As previously explained, functions of external cluster validity measurements can use two inputs for their calculations.

sections.heading: IV. TESTS AND RESULTS
sections.text: We used two types of data to measure changes over time: first, synthesis data is used to verify the validity of the method and to show the efficiency of various proposed metrics to evaluate the amount of changes that occur between two points in time with the data set; second, there are two different sets of public goods data that are used to measure the deviation of players "behavior from their first round and other later rounds.

sections.heading: A. Tests with Synthesised Data
sections.text: In order to simulate the next time, a certain number of items are moved from one cluster to another by changing the items "X and / or Y coordinate signs. In addition, the number of items that have jumped from one cluster to another is determined by a suede random function, with values between 0 and 20. In addition, a small amount of randomized changes are introduced from there to the items to simulate the change that occurred with the items within the same cluster. By repeating these items and jiggs, 19 additional time points are generated from the original dataset, which all produce results in 20 times.The 1Data generator and change measurement codes are available at https: / / goo.gl / 8DBuIIEEE 639 | P a g eSAI Intelligent Systems Conference 2016 metasc.

sections.heading: B. Tests with Public Goods Games Data
sections.text: Two different sets of identical attributes, but different players and different timing lengths, are used to measure how much players differ from their initial timing measurements. [16] Both sets of data have attributes to identify players, set dates, show players "own contributions, show their belief in other players" contributions at each point in time. The first set of data consists of 140 players, each of whom has played 10 rounds, and for the second set of 128 players, each of whom has played 27 rounds. In both sets of data, as they approach the end of the game, players tend to contribute less and their expectations of other players "contributions decrease accordingly. This is shown in Figure 2 for the 10 rounds of game data set. This decrease in contribution might not be an indication of concept drift, as players in the same class all begin to follow the same pattern, reducing their expectations of other players" contributions.

sections.heading: V. MEASURING PLAYERS’ STRATEGY CHANGES USING
sections.text: MONICWe used MONIC2 to gain more insight into the data on public goods and to compare our results with existing methods for measuring cluster changes at different times. Data for each period were bundled separately using k-means with four clusters. However, clustering was performed on the most important temporal attributes of the data, namely belief and contribution, then the data and cluster names of objects appeared in each consistent pair of time points fed to the MONIC algorithm to calculate changes in clusters from one time to another. The algorithm calculated the number of surviving, appearing and disappearing clusters, as shown in numbers 6 and 7, for the ten rounds of the game.

sections.heading: VI. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In the proposed method, each element is clustered individually at each point in time using the same parameters and cluster algorithms. Once the difference between the elements has been clustered, cluster names of the first cluster and other consistent clusters are measured instead of ground truth labels and provided clusters, a method that has been proven to work well for both synthetic and real game data of public goods. Synthetic metrics such as Rand, VI and AUC work very well by reflecting the number of jumps in a quantifiable scaler. Other metrics such as Jaccard and FM were very good at detecting changes, but they tended to exaggerate the amount of changes that took place in clusters. For public goods data sets, it was possible to gradually change from one point in time to another small number of players who had drifted away from their original clusters in both 10 and 27 rounds.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
sections.text: The authors would like to thank Simon Gaechter and Felix Kolle from the School of Economics at the University of Nottingham for providing us with data from the experiment on public goods and for taking the time to explain it to us.

referenceMentions.context: In experimental economics there is an interest in how players of public goods game change their strategy during multiple rounds of the game play and jump from one type of player into another [1], such as changing from conditional co-operator to free rider behaviour (game and player types are described in detail in later sections).
[2], concept drift is an unexpected change from the targeted future estimation due to uncalculated hidden contexts in the system.
Tsymbal [3] identified two types of concept drift: sudden and gradual.
There are many methods in machine learning for classification, with the existence of concept drift [4]–[6] and methods to detect it [7], [8].

External cluster validity is primarily used to check the performance of clustering algorithms by measuring the difference between ground truth labels given to the items by experts and the group in which they have been placed by a clustering algorithm [12].

This study uses external cluster validity measures like variation of information [13]and area under the curve of receiver operating characteristic [14] as scaler measures, to show the amount of items that jumped from one cluster to another between two consequent time points.

Public good is any type of services or resources that cannot be withheld from individuals without competition to benefit from these resources and services due to their characteristics of being non-rivalry and non-excludable [15].
There are many slightly different variations of this game, however the data which has been used in this paper as a case study is based on the model of Fischbacher et al [16].
The public goods game experiment of Fischbacher et al [16] consists of four players, each of whom has a choice to contribute in a project representing the public good.

However, regardless of players’ potential adjustment of their contribution behaviour during multiple rounds (10 rounds or more), economists [17] classify them based on a contribution table of static data filled once by the players prior to the game rounds.

If a pair of points is in different clusters and each point has different labels, this is true negative (TN); otherwise, the pair is false negative (FN) [20].

3) Area Under the Curve: Area Under the Curve (AUC) of receiver operating characteristic (ROC) is a scalar measure originally used by Bradley [14] to calculate the performance of machine learning algorithms, such as classification.

Furthermore, different ways of dealing with data and clustering have been presented, such as MONIC model [24], which targets detecting cluster transition over accumulated data.
Another method introduced by Gnnemann et al [25] traces cluster evolution as change in behaviour of items’ recorded values in high dimensional data sets.

Hawwash and Nasraoui [26] introduced a framework of data stream mining using statistical cluster measures like cardinality, scale and density of clusters to detect milestones of clusters change and monitoring the behaviour of clusters.

Another method presented by Kalnis et al [27] for clustering moving objects in the snapshots of spatio-temporal data is cluster mapping function, by which clusters are treated as sets and the cardinality ratio of intersection is calculated at each two time constitutive clusters over their union.

As Keser and Winden [29] suggest, this change might be due to the players responding to the average contribution of other players in the previous round.

As the MONIC algorithm was originally introduced to detect cluster changes in data stream, it uses an ageing factor which reduces the effect of older items in the cluster and removes items older than two time points [24].

metadata.abstractText: An important issue in public goods game is whether player’s behaviour changes over time, and if so, how significant it is. In this game players can be classified into different groups according to the level of their participation in the public good. This problem can be considered as a concept drift problem by asking the amount of change that happens to the clusters of players over a sequence of game rounds. In this study we present a method for measuring changes in clusters with the same items over discrete time points using external clustering validation indices and area under the curve. External clustering indices were originally used to measure the difference between suggested clusters in terms of clustering algorithms and ground truth labels for items provided by experts. Instead of different cluster label comparison, we use these indices to compare between clusters of any two consecutive time points or between the first time point and the remaining time points to measure the difference between clusters through time points. In theory, any external clustering indices can be used to measure changes for any traditional (nontemporal) clustering algorithm, due to the fact that any time point alone is not carrying any temporal information. For the public goods game, our results indicate that the players are changing over time but the change is smooth and relatively constant between any two time points. Keywords—clustering; external cluster validity; measuring change over time; temporal data
